The product owner of an agile project is frustrated because the team is unable to deliver as many features as expected. The product owner asks the team to reduce test-automation levels, since the quality assurance team will test the product at project completion. The product owner expects that more features will be delivered in each iteration using this approach.
What should the agile practitioner do?

Midway through a two-week sprint, an agile team realizes that the features cannot be delivered within the sprint. The team determines that another week will be required to complete all committed features.
What should the team do?

choices.D: Add resources to assist with sprint execution
choices.A: Plan for overtime, and include the effort as part of the estimation
choices.C: Identify the reason for over-commitment to the sprint and create an action plan for the following sprint
choices.B: Increase team velocity to deliver more story points

discussion.content: Any incomplete stories will be taken back to PBL, period, Adding new resources is risky and costly, and makes no sense for having timebox. So C is the most appropriate answer.
It should be C

Selected Answer: C
Understanding Over-commitment: The team should analyze why they over-committed. This could involve looking at estimation errors, unexpected complexities, or unforeseen issues.
Learning and Adapting: By identifying the root cause, the team can adjust their planning and estimation processes to avoid similar issues in the future.
Continuous Improvement: Agile methodologies emphasize learning from each iteration. Creating an action plan for the next sprint ensures that the team continuously improves their processes.
Maintaining Sprint Integrity: Extending the sprint or adding resources can disrupt the rhythm and predictability of the sprint cycle, which is not advisable in agile practices.
Focus on Value Delivery: The team should prioritize delivering the most valuable features and possibly defer less critical ones to future sprints.

discussion.content: Sprint Demo (AKA Sprint Review) is the event where the stakeholders are invited by PO. Sprint retrospective involves only the scrum team (DT, PO,SM)

comments.content:
Detailed Points:
Transparency: The sprint demo provides a clear view of the progress and the work completed during the sprint.
Stakeholder Feedback: It allows stakeholders, including the IT director, to provide feedback on the deliverables, ensuring alignment with business needs.
Engagement: Inviting the IT director to the sprint demo keeps them engaged and informed about the project's progress and challenges.
Decision Making: The feedback received during the sprint demo can influence future planning and prioritization, making it a critical touchpoint for stakeholders.
Showcasing Progress: It is an opportunity for the team to showcase their achievements and discuss any adjustments needed based on stakeholder input.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
As an active project stakeholder, the IT director should be invited to the sprint demo. The sprint demo, also known as the sprint review, is a meeting where the team demonstrates the completed work to key stakeholders and invites feedback. This meeting increases transparency and provides better opportunities for stakeholders to steer the team.

Option C: Sprint demo is the most appropriate choice.
